Classes

NPAResult

Class for storing and accessing the results of a Network Perturbation Analysis (NPA). It is recommended

NPAResultBuilder

Class for building NPAResult objects. Node attributes can be only passed for nodes in the graph with type "core".
class perturbationx.result.NPAResult(graph: networkx.DiGraph, datasets: list, global_info: pandas.DataFrame, node_info: pandas.DataFrame, distributions: dict, metadata=None)

Class for storing and accessing the results of a Network Perturbation Analysis (NPA). It is recommended to build an NPAResult object using NPAResultBuilder to ensure correct formatting. Metadata is prefixed with “network_” to avoid conflicts, unless the metadata key already starts with “network” or “dataset”. By default, the following metadata is added: datetime_utc, python_implementation, python_version, system_name, system_release, system_version, network_title, network_collection, perturbationx_version, numpy_version, networkx_version, pandas_version, scipy_version, matplotlib_version, seaborn_version, and py4cytoscape_version.

Parameters:

  • graph (networkx.DiGraph) – The network graph.

  • datasets (list) – The datasets used for the analysis.

  • global_info (pandas.DataFrame) – The global information for each dataset.

  • node_info (pandas.DataFrame) – The node information for each dataset.

  • distributions (dict) – The distributions for each permutation.

  • metadata (dict, optional) – Additional metadata to store with the result.

get_distribution(distribution: str, dataset: str, include_reference=False)

Get the distribution for a permutation.

Parameters:

  • distribution (str) – The permutation to get the distribution for.

  • dataset (str) – The dataset to get the distribution for.

  • include_reference (bool, optional) – If True, the reference value will be included in the distribution. Defaults to False.

Returns:

The distribution for the permutation. If include_reference is True, a tuple of the distribution and the reference value will be returned.

Return type:

list | (list, float)

plot_distribution(distribution: str, datasets=None, show=True)

Plot the distribution for a permutation.

Parameters:

  • distribution (str) – The permutation to plot the distribution for.

  • datasets (list, optional) – The datasets to plot the distribution for. If None, all datasets will be plotted.

  • show (bool, optional) – If True, the plot will be shown. Defaults to True.

Returns:

The axes of the plot.

Return type:

matplotlib.axes.Axes

get_leading_nodes(dataset: str, cutoff=0.8, attr='contribution', abs_value=True)

Get the leading nodes for a dataset. The leading nodes are the nodes that contribute the most to a selected attribute, up to a certain cutoff.

Parameters:

  • dataset (str) – The dataset to get the leading nodes for.

  • cutoff (float, optional) – The cutoff for the cumulative distribution. Defaults to 0.8.

  • attr (str, optional) – The node attribute to get the leading nodes for. Defaults to “contribution”.

  • abs_value (bool, optional) – If True, the absolute value of the attribute will be used. Defaults to True.

Returns:

The leading nodes for the dataset.

Return type:

set

get_node_subgraph(nodes, include_shortest_paths='none', path_length_tolerance=0, include_neighbors=0, neighborhood_type='union')

Get the subgraph for a set of nodes. The subgraph can include the shortest paths between the nodes, the neighborhood of the nodes, or both.

Parameters:

  • nodes (set) – The nodes to get the subgraph for.

  • include_shortest_paths (str, optional) – If “directed”, the directed shortest paths between the nodes will be included. If “undirected”, the undirected shortest paths between the nodes will be included. If “none”, no shortest paths will be included. Defaults to “none”.

  • path_length_tolerance (int | float, optional) – The tolerance for the length of the shortest paths. If 0, only the shortest paths are returned. If length_tolerance is an integer, it is interpreted as an absolute length. If length_tolerance is a float, it is interpreted as a percentage of the length of the shortest path. Defaults to 0.

  • include_neighbors (int, optional) – The maximum distance from leading nodes that neighbors can be. If 0, no neighbors will be included. If 1, only the neighbors of the nodes will be included. If 2, the neighbors of the neighbors of the nodes will be included, and so on. Defaults to 0.

  • neighborhood_type (str, optional) – The type of neighborhood to include. Can be one of “union” or “intersection”. If “union”, all nodes within the maximum distance from any leading node are returned. If “intersection”, only nodes within the maximum distance from all leading nodes are returned. Defaults to “union”.

Raises:

ValueError – If include_shortest_paths is not “directed”, “undirected”, or “none”. If max_distance is less than 0 or neighborhood_type is not “union” or “intersection”. If length_tolerance is not a number or is negative.

Returns:

The nodes and edges in the subgraph. They are returned as a pair of lists.

Return type:

(list, list)

display_network(display_boundary=False, style=DEFAULT_STYLE, cytoscape_url=DEFAULT_BASE_URL)

Display the network in Cytoscape.

Parameters:

  • display_boundary (bool, optional) – If True, boundary nodes will be displayed. Defaults to False.

  • style (str, optional) – The style to apply to the network. Defaults to DEFAULT_STYLE (“perturbationx-default”).

  • cytoscape_url (str, optional) – The URL of the Cytoscape instance to display the network in. Defaults to DEFAULT_BASE_URL in py4cytoscape (http://127.0.0.1:1234/v1).

Returns:

The display object.

Return type:

perturbationx.NPAResultDisplay

to_networkx()

Retrieve the NetworkX graph for this result.

Returns:

The NetworkX graph.

Return type:

networkx.DiGraph

to_dict()

Convert this result to a dictionary.

Returns:

The result as a dictionary. Top-level keys are “metadata” and dataset names. For each dataset, the top-level keys are “global_info”, “node_info”, and “distributions”.

Return type:

dict

to_json(filepath: str, indent=4)

Save this result to a JSON file. The format is the same as the output of to_dict().

Parameters:

  • filepath (str) – The path to save the result to.

  • indent (int, optional) – The indentation to use. Defaults to 4.

class perturbationx.result.NPAResultBuilder(graph: networkx.DiGraph, datasets: list)

Class for building NPAResult objects. Node attributes can be only passed for nodes in the graph with type “core”. Each core node should have an attribute “idx” that is a unique integer index for that node. Node attributes should be passed as a list of values that is ordered by the node indices.

Parameters:

  • graph (networkx.DiGraph) – The graph used to generate the result.

  • datasets (list) – The datasets used to generate the result.

classmethod new_builder(graph: networkx.DiGraph, datasets: list)

Construct a new NPAResultBuilder object.

set_global_attributes(dataset_id: str, attributes: list, values: list)

Set global attributes for a dataset. Attributes and values should be ordered in the same way.

Parameters:

  • dataset_id (str) – Dataset to set attributes for.

  • attributes (list) – List of attribute names.

  • values (list) – List of attribute values.

set_node_attributes(dataset_id: str, attributes: list, values: list)

Set node attributes for a dataset. Attributes and values should be ordered in the same way. Values should be passed as a nested list that is ordered by the node indices.

Parameters:

  • dataset_id (str) – Dataset to set attributes for.

  • attributes (list) – List of attribute names.

  • values (list) – List of attribute values.

set_distribution(dataset_id: str, distribution: str, values: list, reference=None)

Set a distribution for a dataset.

Parameters:

  • dataset_id (str) – Dataset to set distribution for.

  • distribution (str) – Name of distribution.

  • values (list) – List of values.

  • reference (float, optional) – Reference value for distribution. Defaults to None.

Parameters:

metadata (dict, optional) – Metadata to include in the result. Defaults to None.

NPAResult object.
